---
title: Gather
---



<div id="the-gather-function" class="section level1">
<h1>The <code>gather()</code> Function</h1>
<p>The second <code>tidyr</code> function we will look into is the <code>gather()</code> function. With <code>gather()</code> it may not be clear what exactly is going on, but in this case we actually have a lot of column names the represent what we would like to have as data values.</p>
<div class="figure">
<img src="data:image/png;base64," />

</div>
<p>For example, in the last <code>spread()</code> practice you created a data frame where variable names were individual years. This may not be what you want to have so you can use the gather function. The picture above displays what this looks like. Consider <code>table4</code>:</p>
<pre><code>## # A tibble: 3 × 3
##       country `1999` `2000`
##        &lt;fctr&gt;  &lt;int&gt;  &lt;int&gt;
## 1 Afghanistan    745   2666
## 2      Brazil  37737  80488
## 3       China 212258 213766</code></pre>
<p>This looks similar to the table you created in the <code>spread()</code> practice. We now wish to change this data frame so that <code>year</code> is a variable and 1999 and 2000 become values instead of variables. We will accomplish this with the gather function:</p>
<pre><code>gather(data, key, value, ...)</code></pre>
<p>where</p>
<ul>
<li><code>data</code> is the dataframe you are working with.</li>
<li><code>key</code> is the name of the <code>key</code> column to create.</li>
<li><code>value</code> is the name of the <code>value</code> column to create.</li>
<li><code>...</code> is a way to specify what columns to gather from.</li>
</ul>
<div id="gather-example" class="section level2">
<h2><code>gather()</code> Example</h2>
<p>In our example here we would do the following: `</p>
<pre class="r"><code>table4 %&gt;%
    gather(&quot;year&quot;, &quot;cases&quot;, 2:3)</code></pre>
<pre><code>## # A tibble: 6 × 3
##       country  year  cases
##        &lt;fctr&gt; &lt;chr&gt;  &lt;int&gt;
## 1 Afghanistan  1999    745
## 2      Brazil  1999  37737
## 3       China  1999 212258
## 4 Afghanistan  2000   2666
## 5      Brazil  2000  80488
## 6       China  2000 213766</code></pre>
<p>You can see that we have created 2 new columns called <code>year</code> and <code>cases</code>. We filled these with the previous 2nd and 3rd columns. Note that we could have done this in many different ways too. For example if we knew the years but not which columns we could do this:</p>
<pre><code>table4 %&gt;%
    gather(&quot;year&quot;, &quot;cases&quot;, &quot;1999&quot;:&quot;2000&quot;)</code></pre>
<p>We could also see that we want to gather all columns except the first so we could have used:</p>
<pre><code>table4 %&gt;%
    gather(&quot;year&quot;, &quot;cases&quot;, -1)</code></pre>
<p>All of these will yield the same results.</p>
<div class="content-box-green">
<h1>
On Your Own: RStudio Practice
</h1>
<p>Create <code>population2</code> from last example:</p>
<pre class="r"><code>population 2 &lt;- population %&gt;% 
                    spread(year, population)</code></pre>
<p>Now gather the columns that are labeled by year and create columns <code>year</code> and <code>population</code>. In the end your data frame should look like:</p>
<pre><code>## # A tibble: 2 × 3
##       country  year population
##         &lt;chr&gt; &lt;int&gt;      &lt;int&gt;
## 1 Afghanistan  1995   17586073
## 2 Afghanistan  1996   18415307</code></pre>
</div>
</div>
